awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Developing a Quantitative Three-Dimensional Understanding of Cardiac Arrhythmias
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop a better understanding of what initiates some of the most lethal heart rhythms using mathematics and data assimilation methods used in weather forecasting. The detailed behavior of cardiac cells and tissue cannot be measured directly, especially inside of the heart muscle.  This project will develop and validate new ways to estimate the behavior of the heart during abnormal rhythms. The knowledge gained will be used to identify ways that could be used to improve the effectiveness of treatments for these abnormal rhythms as delivered by electrical devices. The research efforts will also contribute to broadening participation of underrepresented groups and integration of research into both classroom teaching and informal education. The success of this project will directly contribute towards the progress of science to advance the national health. 

Many cardiac arrhythmias develop when the propagation of electrical waves through cardiac muscle, a process that triggers contraction, is disrupted. Despite the importance of understanding these arrhythmias and notwithstanding advances made through experimentation and computational modeling, many unanswered questions remain, especially regarding what happens in the typically unobserved thickness of cardiac tissue. This project will involve studying the role of tissue thickness on the development and progression of complicated spatiotemporal dynamics for certain types of arrhythmias such as tachycardia and fibrillation, when experiments often reveal little obvious correlation between surface observations. In particular, the detailed effects of potentially therapeutic electrical interventions will be analyzed. To accomplish these goals, data assimilation, a technique from weather forecasting, will be applied to recover high-resolution estimates of complex cardiac electrical states observed in experiments using spatiotemporally sparse observations of only one state variable. The response of the cardiac system when methods to control the dynamics are applied will be quantified. The resulting improved understanding of the heart's behavior and response to control attempts could lead to improved control methods that can restore normal behavior across the heart's thickness more reliably, more quickly, or with lower energies compared to standard methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project involved studying the problem of reconstructing the spatio-temporal dynamics inside cardiac tissue from detailed system state information when limited observational data are available (heart surfaces) . For this we focused on two main issues,  1) methods to record cardiac activity in live tissue, including human hearts, characterize the variation of cell types across tissue and develop mathematical models that could be later be used with data assimilation methods. 2) reconstructing the complicated spatiotemporal dynamics during cardiac rhythm disturbances called arrhythmias. In experiments, it is possible to record information from the cardiac tissue surfaces, but this information often reveals little obvious correlation between those surface observations, suggesting more complicated dynamics within the tissue thickness. Understanding more details of the dynamics could suggest new avenues for termination of this undesirable behavior.

To address the problem, we developed reliable data-assimilation tools for studying cardiac wave propagation and detailed these results in several papers. In one key paper, we studied the sensitivity of our method to algorithmic and model parameters. We used an ensemble Kalman filter to reconstruct a three-dimensional time series of states with complex spatiotemporal dynamics using only surface observations of voltage and considered the effects of several algorithmic and model parameters on the accuracy of reconstructions of known scroll-wave truth states using synthetic observations. We found that the algorithm could achieve an acceptable level of error in many cases, with the weakest performance occurring for model-error cases and more extreme parameter regimes with more complex dynamics. Analysis of the poorest-performing cases indicated an initial decrease in error followed by an increase when the ensemble spread was reduced, thereby suggesting avenues for further improvement through increasing ensemble spread.

Building on this effort, another key paper focused on applying robust data assimilation with noise to cardiac dynamics, considering that accounting for uncertainties due to model error, observation error, and hidden state variables could improve the accuracy of state reconstructions, including an increase in ensemble spread. Toward this end, we introduced stochastic modeling methods in the context of ensemble-based data assimilation and state reconstruction for cardiac dynamics. We proposed two classes of methods, one following the canonical stochastic differential equation formalism, and another perturbing the ensemble evolution in the parameter space of the model. We found that a combination of stochastic processes yielded improvements to the assimilation error and ensemble spread over these classical methods.

We were also able to perform experiments in live human hearts and quantify for the first time the dynamics of a single spiral wave of voltage and calcium simultaneously in human ventricles. We also were able to show experimentally how these spiral waves destabilize due to the 3D (intramural activity) and formed multiple spiral waves driving the tissue into fibrillation. This was due to development of new techniques to measure with optical mapping through this grant.  

We also leveraged graduate student expertise in experiments and numerical simulations, in particular machine learning to pursue an alternative approach for predicting cardiac voltage data using recurrent neural networks and reservoir computing. We published three papers in this area. In addition, we developed an updated codebase for data assimilation with greater portability and flexibility. We also developed several codes in GPU that allow fast simulations of voltage dynamics in 3D anatomically accurate heart structures.

In terms of broader impacts, multiple graduate students were supported from this work, and four postdocs, results were disseminated in a variety of conferences and publications, and related topics were introduced in new and revised courses. Our work has the potential to help understand specific mechanisms giving rise to arrhythmias in particular experiments, which can inform better ways to terminate, treat, or even prevent such arrhythmias. In addition, our work has applications to other areas: we participated in several collaborative efforts applying the data-assimilation framework to prediction of cellular epithelial-mesenchymal transition, which is a fundamental biological process that plays a central role in embryonic development, tissue regeneration, and cancer metastasis, resulting in several papers.

One of the postdocs is now working as research scientist at the FDA, the two others are now faculty at VCU in the US and at Durham University in the UK.
